repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

did.abstract: This collection contains the papers of Frederick A. Masse, Jr., Tufts alumnus.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Series 2 is the gift of Woburn Public Library, 2016, accession MS-2017-035.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into two series: Frederick A. Masse Jr. papers, and Ethiopian materials.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frederick Arthur Masse, Jr. (circa 1931- April 25, 1987) was born in Woburn, Massachusetts, the son of Frederick A. and Mildred A. (Grimes) Masse and one of five children: Shirley, Francis, David, and Myrna. He received his B.A. from Tufts in English (A 1952). He served later on in the U. S. Foreign Service in Ethiopia in the early 1960s. During his life, Masse taught in Ethiopia, Iran, Sudan, Great Britain and Newport, RI. Masse was an English teacher for the Ministry of Fine Arts and Education in Addis Ababa 1958-1961 and 1963-1966. During this time he also served as tutor to two of Emperor Hailie Selassie's grandchildren. In 1962-1963 Masse taught high school in Khartoum. He served as a visiting lecturer in English as a Foreign Language at Georgetown University in the summer of 1975. From 1976 to circa 1978 he taught for the Imperial Iranian Navy. He also taught as English instructor at the Washington Technical Institute. After retiring as a teacher, he lived in Miami, Florida. Masse married Margaret Page (Margaret M. Massé), a Howard University graduate, in November 1970, but they were divorced by 1978.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Frederick A. Masse Jr. Papers, 1960 -- 1986. Tufts University. Digital Collections and Archives. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Series one was processed by Jennifer Phillips (2007-03-30), supervised by Susanne Belovari. Series two was processed by Leah Edelman in 2017. Materials were placed in archival boxes if the orignal housing was damaged, and loose materials were placed in folders where needed. A box-level inventory and series-level description were created and the finding aid was updated at the time of processing.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Please consult the "Ethiopian Materials Collection" in Special Collections at Michigan State University for additional papers by Frederick Massé.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains Frederick A. Masse's personal correspondence and an autobiographical text, "Royal Bastards and Freed Slaves Volume 1," as well as materials documenting Masse's experiences working for the US Foreign Service in Ethiopia in the 1960s and 1970s, including scrapbooks, photographs, sketchbooks, journals, correspondence, publications, and memorabilia such as drawings, a wooden Ethiopian cross, and human hair.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection for the first accession. Any intellectual property rights that the donor possesses in the second accession have been transferred to Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Content Warning
scopecontent.p: This finding aid contains language that may be offensive or outdated. Because such language is in titles or direct transcription of materials, it has not been changed. Keeping this language intact provides the most accurate depiction of the creators' intent, and can potentially tell us important things about bigotry and bias on the part of the creators, or in a particular historical context. It can also preserve terms formerly applied by a group to self-identify that have since fallen out of common usage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains an autobiographical text covering part of Frederick A. Masse's time in Ethiopia (1960-1961). It also includes photocopies of his personal correspondence which he bound in volumes. The series contains volumes 2-5. Volumes, 1, 6 and 7 are missing.

did.unittitle: Autobiographical Trilogy on living in Ethiopia, "Royal Bastards and Freed Slaves Volume 1"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Text consists of journal entries from 1960-61 covering the coup d'etat and earthquakes, but Masse organized and copyrighted the material in 1980.

physdesc.extent: One record carton and four 12x16" flat boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series documents Tufts alum Frederick A. Masse Jr.'s experiences living in Ethiopia in the 1960s and 1970s as an employee of the US Foreign Service. It comprises scrapbooks, photograph albums and loose photographs, sketchbooks, appointment books and calendars, journals, correspondence, publications, and memorabilia. Included are drawings, a wooden Ethiopian cross, a framed painting, and human hair.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by format.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: One diary restricted at request of donor.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Folder 11 restricted by request of donor.
